questions.text: A 42-year-old man who was under home isolation after testing positive for COVID-19 develops breathing difficulty and is brought to the ER. The patient is alert and responsive but is breathing rapidly. SpO 2 is measured to be 86%. He is administered oxygen via a face mask with a reservoir bag with a flow rate of 10 L/min. After a trial of one hour, his SpO 2 is 88%. What is the next step in management?
questions.correct_answer: B. High-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy

questions.text: A patient in the ICU with an endotracheal tube now needs a tracheostomy tube. Which type of tube will you use?

What should be the next course of action in managing a patient with pneumonia who is on a ventilator, weighs 50 kg, has a respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, a bicarbonate level of 18, a pH of 7.33, a paCO2 level of 48 mmHg, a Pao2 level of 110 mmHg, a PEEP of 12 cm H₂O, a tidal volume of 420 mL, and a SpO2 level of 100% with an FiO2 of 90%?

questions.explanation: Correct Option A - LMA P

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is a contraindication for the use of bi-level positive airway pressure?
questions.explanation:
Absolute contraindication

Relative contraindication

Facial trauma/ burn

Altered mental staus/ unconscious (Option B)

Fixed upper airway obstruction

Inability to protect the airway

Active vomiting

Life threatening hypoxemia

Respiratory or cardiac arrest

questions.text: In which of the following is the given position used?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B – Intu

questions.text: A known case of asthmatic bronchitis was reported to the hospital with breathlessness, palpitations, and oxygen saturation of 88%. The hospital does not have a ventilator. All the following can be given to the patient, except?

options.label: C
options.text: Oxygen with oxygen mask, and reservoir

questions.correct_answer: C. Oxygen with oxygen mask, and reservoir
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Oxygen with oxygen mask, and reserv

Aspect

Description

Indications

Hypoxemia due to various causes, such as respiratory failure, pneumonia, or asthma

Oxygen source

Oxygen tank or concentrator

Oxygen delivery devices

Nasal cannula, simple face mask, non-rebreather mask, venturi mask

Oxygen flow rate

Determined by the patient's oxygen saturation and respiratory status

Target oxygen saturation

Generally, 92-96%

Monitoring and titration

Regular assessment of oxygen saturation and respiratory status to adjust oxygen flow rate as needed

Side effects and complications

Oxygen toxicity, absorption atelectasis, drying of nasal mucosa, CO2 retention in chronic respiratory failure

Special considerations

Caution in patients with COPD, as high flow oxygen can cause hypercapnia and respiratory failure

questions.text: Which of the following is not a clear benefit of using high-pressure oxygen via nasal cannula?
questions.correct_answer: A. Decreases the need of intubation
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A. Decreases the need for intu

A

High-pressure oxygen through nasal cannula does not decrease the need for intubation.

B

High-pressure oxygen through nasal cannula can reduce nasopharyngeal dead space.

C

Adequate heating and humidification should be provided with high-pressure oxygen through nasal cannula to prevent drying of the respiratory mucosa.

D

High-pressure oxygen through nasal cannula does not provide the same level of PEEP (positive end-expiratory pressure) as mechanical ventilation.
